using NTFS can be a pain and when users say they have issues doing basic data storage it is nearly always because they are using junky NTFS
I suggest you check the mount options, make sure it i swritable and writable by users. If the partition is USB based then be sure you use the safe remove option before you unplug it
so this problem arose suddenly? and what do u mean by Junky NTFS?
NTFS cannot hold Linux permissions, so you need to set the file accessing at mount time to apply to the whole storage rather than granular settings like the Lnux file systems you have
how can i make sure that it is writable? no it's my hdd
add an option in /etc/fstab to mount the NTFS at boot and you can define the options to give users write access
let me make myself clear.....i'm a begginer in ubuntu...so plz give me instructions so that i can do it....thnx dude

there are plenty of guides online for how to add an NTFS partition to /etc/fstab   I gotta jet now but a bit of searching online will show you how. Its not hard at all. You will need:  sudo blkid    to get the UUID of the NTFS partition and:  gksudo gedit /etc/fstab   to get write access to the file.
